p.s: The author starts with a shocking fact to get the readersreader's attention and attract the right target group: The middle-right conservastists of Great Britain who are looking at the immigrants with a suspicious look.
It's conspiciuousconspicious that the author puts in the end of every paragraph a controversial statement or argument to either scare the readers or to underline his arguments of the paragraph.
The metaphor Every year Bangladeshis sit at the bottom of educational achievement (l. 7) explains the bad and unchanging level of education in a pictorial way to get the message better to the reader.
The metaphermetaphor in line 9 and 10 extremists in the mosque or the gangs in the streets is a again a good way to deliver the message succesfullysuccessfully to the reader.
The majority of us had no experience with extremists or gangs but we all know mosque or some dangerous streets.
What the author does here is to link the dangerous and scary organisations with ordinary, normal things in our everydayseveryday life to connect the fear to something we all know.

The metaphermetaphor you don't learn to stand on your own two feet if someone is holding you up (l. 18-19) is a simple and easy way to say that you can't learn to live in Great Britain with all the rules and culture you have to acknowledge when someone gives you a way to avoid such things.
